title: Handbook Template
text:
Welcome
This is a template for creating (hand)books styled for VU Amsterdam.
To get started you only need a GitHub account. You can find the template directly on GitHub. If you need any help to set it up, contact chris@libscie.org.

title: Handbook Template
text:
Contributors






Note



Note that there are five types of callouts, including: note, warning, important, tip, and caution.








Warning with Title



This is an example of a callout with a title.








important with Title



This is an example of a callout with a title.








Tip with Title



This is an example of a callout with a title.








Expand To Learn About Collapse





This is an example of a ‘folded’ caution callout that can be expanded by the user. You can use collapse="true" to collapse it by default or collapse="false" to make a collapsible callout that is expanded by default.

title: 1  Example chapter
text:
1.1 Section
This is an example section. Once you include a section this way there will be a table of contents on the page too!




Knuth, Donald E. 1984. “Literate Programming.” Comput. J. 27 (2): 97–111. https://doi.org/10.1093/comjnl/27.2.97.

title: Contributing
text:
Suggesting edits
The easiest and quickest way to contribute to the book is make suggested edits. On each page you will find a button reading “Edit this page” (usually on the right).



Screenshot of a handbook chapter, with a red box on the right hand side of the page indicating where to find the “Edit this page” button


When you click that, you will immediately be taken to GitHub to edit the text of that specific page.
Once you made your edits, you are ready to submit your pull request!

title: Contributing
text:
Adding a chapter
To add a new chapter, you need to create a new file ending in .qmd (e.g., data-stewardship.qmd).
The chapter itself needs to be written in Markdown. Every chapter must contain a first level heading (e.g., # Heading), which will be the chapter title.
After you created your chapter, you need to add it to the chapters list in _quarto.yml. You can find the chapters list around line 24.
After that, you are ready to submit your pull request!

title: Contributing
text:
Submit a pull request
A pull request is a way to request for your changes to be incorporated into the book. This means that the people managing the book will review what you wrote, and accept or decline your contributions.

title: Contributing
text:
Writing text
The book is created using Markdown - you can get familiarized with the basic syntax on the Markdown website](https://www.markdownguide.org/basic-syntax). The basics are:
# Heading level 1
## Heading level 2
### Heading level 3

You simply write text as you are used to. To make something *italic*, **bold**, or ***bold and italic***.

> this is how you add quotes

- or lists
- that can go on 
- and on
You can utilize more styling of your writing, but these are the basics. If you want to add code, use references, create links, or footnotes - it is all possible. We will expand examples here based on your needs, so if you need help, let us know by reporting an issue!

title: Contributing
text:
GitHub
We use GitHub to create this website automatically, and to manage all the incoming updates. You do not need to know how it works entirely, but we want to help you understand some things so you are not confused.

Repository
A repository on GitHub is like a folder on your computer. This can do many things, depending on what files it contains. When we mention a repository, we mean that we want you to look at a specific folder. The repository for this website for example can be found on GitHub directly](https://github.com/ubvu/handbook-template).


Forking
A repository is owned by one or multiple people on GitHub. If you are not one of them, you can create a copy to make your edits in. This act of creating a copy is called “forking.”

title: References
text:

J. 27 (2): 97–111. https://doi.org/10.1093/comjnl/27.2.97.
